keyTakeAways: Chernihiv, Ukraine, experienced a total blackout due to a massive Russian assault involving over 100 Iranian-designed Shahed drones and six ballistic missiles.
The attack targeted electricity generating facilities, leading to a complete loss of power across Chernihiv and surrounding areas.
Four people were killed and ten injured, including a 10-year-old girl, in residential neighborhoods of Novhorod-Siverskyi.
The region is the most northerly in Ukraine and shares borders with both Russia and Belarus, which limits air defense response time.

Ukrainian officials, including Andriy Podorvan, deputy head of Chernihiv Regional Military Administration, describe a significant increase in attacks on civilian infrastructure over the past two months.
Russia is reportedly targeting civilian infrastructure, such as petrol stations and water pumping stations, not just military targets.
Loss of power has disrupted water supply, forcing residents to stock up on bottled water or rely on emergency deliveries.
Restoration efforts have been delayed due to the scale of damage and limited availability of replacement equipment; a single transformer can take over a year to produce.
Total damage to Ukraine's energy infrastructure is estimated at over $16 billion (€13.7 billion; £11.9 billion).
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met with US President Donald Trump and US energy leaders, with the latter meetings reportedly successful in discussing energy sector support.
Despite the attacks, civilians in Chernihiv maintain high morale, with back-up generators, community support, and a sense of collective resilience.
Officials believe Russia's focus on civilian infrastructure reflects a misjudgment, as Ukrainians recognize the enemy and remain united.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Chernihiv, Ukraine, is in a total blackout after a massive Russian missile and drone attack involving over 100 Iranian-designed Shahed drones and six ballistic missiles, which destroyed critical power generation facilities. The attack killed four people and injured ten, including a 10-year-old girl, and severely disrupted water supplies. The region, bordering Russia and Belarus, is vulnerable due to limited defense response time. Officials report a sharp increase in attacks on civilian infrastructure, including petrol stations and water systems, suggesting Russia is targeting public resilience rather than military objectives. Ukraine’s energy sector is under immense strain, with replacement equipment taking over a year to produce, and damage costs exceeding $16 billion. Despite the devastation, civilians maintain high morale, with community support and back-up systems enabling daily life. Diplomatic efforts by President Volodymyr Zelensky with US energy leaders have yielded positive outcomes in support of energy recovery, signaling hope for long-term resilience.
title: Ukraine: Chernihiv in total blackout after 'massive' Russian assault
